imageAlt: Lateral view of a human chest showing lung lobe boundaries.
stem: The nurse is auscultating the lungs of a client with suspected pneumonia. Click on the anatomical location most appropriate for evaluating the Right Middle Lobe.

hotspots.label: Right Middle Lobe (Lateral)
hotspots.feedback: Correct! The Right Middle Lobe is best auscultated on the right lateral chest.

hotspots.label: Left Upper Lobe
hotspots.feedback: Incorrect. The Left Upper Lobe is on the opposite side of the body.

hotspots.label: Right Lower Lobe
hotspots.feedback: Incorrect. While on the correct side, the Right Lower Lobe is not the primary location for auscultating the Right Middle Lobe.

rationale.correct: The Right Middle Lobe (RML) is best auscultated on the right lateral chest, approximately at the 4th-5th intercostal space. Pneumonia often causes consolidation in the affected lobe. Auscultation over consolidated lung tissue typically reveals bronchial breath sounds (louder, higher pitched) and possible crackles (rales) due to fluid accumulation in the alveoli. The RML's anatomical position makes it particularly susceptible to aspiration pneumonia in supine patients.
rationale.incorrect: The posterior chest primarily allows auscultation of the upper and lower lobes due to their posterior location. The left lung only has two lobes (upper and lower), so selecting a location on the left side would not assess the right middle lobe.
clinicalPearls: Always assess the right lateral chest to avoid missing middle-lobe consolidation, especially in patients at risk for aspiration.
Consider the patient's position when assessing lung sounds; gravity affects fluid distribution.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: Remember the right lung has 3 lobes and the left has 2. Visualize the anatomical location of each lobe before auscultating.

reviewUnits.heading: Lungs
reviewUnits.body: Anatomy determines the approach to physical assessment. Understanding lung lobe location is crucial for accurate auscultation and diagnosis.

sbar.situation: A 68-year-old client is admitted with suspected pneumonia, requiring lung auscultation to identify affected lobes.
sbar.background: The client presents with a fever of 101.5°F (38.6°C), productive cough with yellow sputum, and shortness of breath. The client has a history of COPD and is a former smoker. Oxygen saturation is 90% on room air.
sbar.assessment: At 08:00, auscultation reveals diminished breath sounds and coarse crackles in the right lateral chest, specifically at the 4th-5th intercostal space. Respiratory rate is 24 breaths per minute and labored. The client reports pleuritic chest pain.
sbar.recommendation: Report findings to the provider immediately. Obtain a chest X-ray to confirm pneumonia and identify the extent of consolidation. Initiate oxygen therapy to maintain SpO2 > 92%. Administer antibiotics as prescribed. Monitor respiratory status closely (SpO2, respiratory rate, work of breathing) every 02:00. Encourage coughing and deep breathing exercises.

imageAlt: Illustration of a chest with markers for Aortic, Pulmonic, Erb's, Tricuspid, and Mitral points.
stem: The nurse is assessing a client for an aortic murmur. Click on the area where the aortic valve is best auscultated.

hotspots.label: Aortic (2nd ICS RSB)
hotspots.feedback: Correct! The aortic valve is best auscultated at the 2nd intercostal space, right sternal border (2nd ICS RSB).

hotspots.label: Pulmonic
hotspots.feedback: Incorrect. The pulmonic area (2nd ICS LSB) is where the pulmonic valve is best auscultated.

hotspots.label: Mitral
hotspots.feedback: Incorrect. The mitral area (5th ICS MCL) is where the mitral valve is best auscultated.

rationale.correct: The aortic valve is best auscultated at the 2nd intercostal space, right sternal border (2nd ICS RSB). This location corresponds to the anatomical position where blood flow from the aorta is closest to the chest wall, allowing for optimal detection of aortic valve sounds and murmurs.
rationale.incorrect: The pulmonic area (2nd ICS LSB) is where the pulmonic valve is best auscultated. The mitral area (5th ICS MCL) is where the mitral valve is best auscultated. Auscultating in the incorrect location will not allow for accurate assessment of the aortic valve.
clinicalPearls: Auscultation should be performed in a systematic manner to ensure all valve areas are assessed.
Aortic murmurs may indicate aortic stenosis or regurgitation.
Use the diaphragm of the stethoscope for high-pitched sounds like aortic murmurs.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: Aortic is the ONLY point on the Right Sternal Border.

reviewUnits.heading: Cardiac Exam
reviewUnits.body: Structured auscultation ensures all valves are assessed.

sbar.situation: The client is a 72-year-old male being assessed for a possible aortic valve abnormality during a routine physical exam.
sbar.background: The client has a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and recent complaints of exertional dyspnea and occasional chest pain. He denies any history of rheumatic fever.
sbar.assessment: At 14:00, auscultation is being performed to assess for the presence of an aortic murmur. The aortic valve area is located at the 2nd intercostal space, right sternal border. A harsh, systolic ejection murmur is auscultated at the aortic area, radiating to the neck.
sbar.recommendation: Further evaluation with echocardiography is warranted to assess the severity of the aortic stenosis. Notify the provider of the abnormal findings immediately. Monitor the client's blood pressure and heart rate. Educate the client on the importance of adhering to prescribed medications and lifestyle modifications.
